title: Ubisoft moves back big 'Watch Dogs,' 'Rainbow Six' releases by up to a year
text:
'Watch Dogs Legion' is now expected mid- to late-2020 on PlayStation 4, Xbox One, PC and Stadia

Difficulties with the launches of "The Division 2" and "Ghost Recon: Wildlands" have led global video game publisher Ubisoft to delay "Watch Dogs: Legion," "Rainbow Six Quarantine" and "Gods & Monsters" out of

early 2020 in order to deliver optimal experiences for players, staff, and shareholders.

As part of an October 24 investors call, French-headquartered video game giant Ubisoft confirmed underperforming launches for its most recent top-tier releases, "The Division 2" and "Tom Clancy's Ghost Recon Wildlands."

That appears to have prompted a more cautious timescale for the release dates of three upcoming titles, previously intended to release during the first three months of 2020.

Shifting the launches of "Watch Dogs: Legion," "Tom Clancy's Rainbow Six Quarantine," and "Gods & Monsters" to between July and December 2020 would allow Ubisoft's teams to "deliver optimal experiences for players" and "maximize the future value of our brands for the long-term benefit of our employees, players, and shareholders."

In other words, it's better to take a financial hit over the next six months than deal with the longer-term fallout from making more poorly performing games.

"Watch Dogs: Legion," third in a cyber-vigilante franchise, moves the series from the USA to a post-Brexit dystopian London under authoritarian rule.

It'll be up to the player to recruit and switch between members of a resistance movement whose followers could be anything from a cryptocurrency specialist to a taser-wielding pensioner.

Revealed in June, "Watch Dogs Legion" had initially been announced for March 2020.

Squad-based tactical shooter "Tom Clancy's Rainbow Six Quarantine" is to pit three players against enemies hosting a new breed of alien parasites.

It's been spun off from the successful "Rainbow Six Siege," which had been steadily improved as Ubisoft further developed the base game and added new content after an initial 2015 release.

"Quarantine" did not have a precise 2020 date upon its own announcement in June but Ubisoft indicated that, up until now, it had been aiming for sometime before the end of March.

Finally, mythological adventure "Gods & Monsters," which benefited from comparisons to Nintendo's "The Legend of Zelda: Breath of the Wild," had been anticipated for February 2020.

Similarities to "Breath of the Wild" were in its favor, given that "Gods & Monsters" would release on PlayStation 4, Xbox One, PC and game streaming service Google Stadia as well as the Nintendo Switch.

Moving away from early 2020 has become an October 2019 trend, after Sony Interactive Entertainment's decision to delay tentpole "The Last of Us Part II" to May, and a hold on "Vampire: The Masquerade - Bloodlines 2."

Consequently, those that remain could benefit from bigger opportunities -- "Darksiders Genesis," "Final Fantasy VII Remake," "Ori and the Will of the Wisps," for example -- though even late March's high-powered shooter "Doom Eternal" will be aware of the impact of an eagerly awaited "Cyberpunk 2077," due midway through April.
